content.html:
Activity

A flag ceremony is held at a Fourth of July event. The height of the flag is a function of time.

Here are some graphs that could each be a possible representation of the function.



    1. For each graph assigned to you, explain what it tells us about the flag. 

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

  • Graph A: The flag starts out on the ground but is immediately raised at a constant rate.
  • Graph B: The flag starts out at 3 meters above ground and then stays at that height the entire time.
  • Graph C: The flag starts out on the ground but gets pulled up quickly. The movement slows down and there is a brief pause, and then it is raised up again at a quicker and quicker rate.
  • Graph D: The flag starts out on the ground, is raised up a couple of meters, and then is lowered back to the ground. This happens repeatedly.
  • Graph E: The flag starts out at 0.5 meter above the ground and is raised up bit by bit, with a brief pause before it is raised farther.
  • Graph F: The flag starts out on the ground and is raised up at a constant speed for 3 seconds. It stops abruptly and comes back down at a constant speed. Then, 2 seconds later, it stops at 3 meters above the ground.


    1. Decide as a group which graph(s) appear to be most realistic and which ones least realistic.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

Graph E seems the most realistic. Graphs B and D are the least realistic. Graphs A, C, and F are possible, but it is unlikely that the flag starts out being on the ground.



Video: Interpreting Graphs Without Units

Watch the following video to learn more about how to determine if a graph is realistic when it doesn’t have units.



  1. Here is another graph that relates time and height.


  1. Can this graph represent the time and height of the flag? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

(assuming that time is measured in seconds and height in meters):

No. This graph shows the flag being at all heights between 0 and 6 meters at 3 seconds of time, which is impossible.



  1. Is this a graph of a function? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

(assuming that time is measured in seconds and height in meters):

No, it is not a graph of a function. A function has only one output for every input. This graph shows many possible outputs when the input is 3.


Making a Real-World Connection

Suppose an ant is moving at a rate of 1 millimeter per second and keeps going at that rate for a long time. If time, \(x\), is measured in seconds, then the distance the ant has traveled in millimeters, \(y\), is \(y=1x\). If time, \(x\), is measured in minutes, the distance in millimeters is \(y=60x\).

  1. Explain why the equation \(y=(365\cdot24\cdot3600)x\) gives the distance the ant has traveled, in millimeters, as a function of time, \(x\), in years.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers:

For example: The number of seconds in a year is \(365\cdot24\cdot60\cdot60\). If the ant travels 1 millimeter a second, in one year, it would travel \(365\cdot24\cdot3600\) millimeters. In \(x\) years, it would travel \((365\cdot24\cdot3600)x\) millimeters.




  1. Graph the equation. Use the desmos graphing tool or technology outside the course.

Select the Solution button to check your work.



  1. Does the graph look like that of a function? Why do you think it looks this way?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The graph is a vertical line and doesn’t look like a graph of a function. The slope is really large, so the line is so steep that it looks vertical.


  1. Using graphing technology outside of this course, adjust the graphing window until the graph no longer looks this way. If you manage to do so, describe the graphing window that you use.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The graph is a slanted line when the \(x\)-axis is scaled from –0.0001 to 0.0001 years and the \(y\)-axis is scaled to ten thousands in both directions.


  1. Do you think the last graph in the flag activity could represent a function relating time and height of the flag? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Flag F can represent a function because every input goes to exactly one output.
